title: Opinion: Nationals, up 2-0 in World Series, prove scouting still has a place in baseball
text:
USA TODAY

WASHINGTON — They don’t have a single person in their front office from Harvard, Yale or M.I.T.

They believe in pouring money into their scouting and player department.

They have 10 scouts and advisers who are 60 or older – including two who were alive the last time the nation’s capital had a team in the World Series.

They are the Washington Nationals. And they are putting on an old-school beatdown on the Houston Astros.

The Nationals are proving that it’s still cool to believe in old-fashioned scouting, treat players like human beings instead of assets and value experience as a positive instead of a negative.

The first World Series game in Washington since since 1933 will be played Friday night with the Nationals up 2-0, and they’ve got a chance to wrap up the first title in franchise history this weekend.

“I think we’re all thrilled to see what’s happening because of what the Nationals represent,’’ said Arizona Diamondbacks special assistant Gary Hughes, 75. “They still value scouting. They actually go to the ballpark and scout. They see what happens with their own eyes.

“They don’t stay home, watch it on video and TV and make their own reports just off numbers. That’s ridiculous. Really, it’s arrogance.’’

ASTROS: Down in the series, Houston still confident

WORLD SERIES:Donald Trump plans to attend Game 5*

This is an organization that values old-school scouting and experience perhaps more than any other. They have a staff that includes six former scouting directors, four former managers, two former GMs and every member of their pro scouting staff played professional baseball.

The Nationals blanketed the landscape with scouts this postseason. They had two on every team in the playoffs, including five alone on the American League Championship Series.

The Astros, who don’t have a traditional pro scout, never bothered to send a soul to advance the Nationals during the playoffs.

So take a wild guess who the scouting industry wants to win this series.

“My phone is just blowing up,’’ Nats special assistant De Jon Watson said. “When we beat the Dodgers, I had close to 200 friends and people around the industry congratulating us. They know this is great for the game.’’

And a subtle reminder this is still a people’s game, played by players, not assets, where clubhouse culture is critical to a team’s success.

Sure, the Nats wouldn’t be two victories away from a World Series championship without stars Anthony Rendon and Juan Soto, who celebrates his 21st birthday Friday. They also wouldn’t be here without 36-year-old Howie Kendrick and 32-year-old reserve outfielder Gerardo Parra.

“The Astros have computer chips to equate their formulas,’’ said Johnny DiPuglio, the Nationals' director of international scouting. “We have people. We don’t get caught up with all of that Trackman , Blast , Statcast stuff that’s being used.

“We watch the players ourselves, sit down with everyone, smoke a cigar and come up with a consensus.’’

Yep, a whole lot like the old days.

“We’re proving the old-school ways still work, and that’s the message we’re sending,’’ said Nats special assistant Dan Jennings, a former GM, manager and farm director. “The last five years, there’s this thought there’s only one way to do things. Hey, this game has been played for over 150 years; there’s definitely more to it than analytics.

“It’s like the veteran scouts used to say: 'Those who can, evaluate. Those who can’t, measure.'

“As long as there are human beings in that dugout, you better understand compassion, heart and all of the things that evaluate the person, and not just the measurement of ability."

No understands this more than Nats GM Mike Rizzo, who has taken full advantage of all the scouting layoffs in the industry, plucking some of the greatest minds in the game.

He surrounds himself with vast experience. One night, he’ll spend games sitting alongside Jack McKeon, 88, the former World Series champion manager and GM. The next night, it's his 89-year-old scout, his father, Phil Rizzo. He’ll have four-time All-Star and seven-time Gold Glove catcher Bob Boone sitting to his left, and Cy Young winner Pete Vuckovich to his right.

There’s an eight-person analytical department that will sit in the back.

“We’re sneaky techies,’’ Rizzo said, “we just don’t talk about it much. But we’re proud of the analytic staff we put together. We didn’t have anyone when I got here, but now we created our own database.’’

The name?

The Pentagon, of course.

“They are sort of sneaky,’’ Astros GM Jeff Luhnow said. “They’re a smart organization. People label us as an analytical organization, but we’ve got really good evaluators. They use their eyes and their guts.

“We’re more similar than people think.’’

Rizzo, 58, is beloved by the scouting community. He’s worshiped for his loyalty and willingness to hire veteran scouts. Luhnow is loathed in the scouting industry, blamed for the rash of scouts out of work with his passion for analytics.

“I just know that I need their minds, I need their information and I knew their experience,’’ Rizzo said. “The only rule I tell our guys is that when I call, answer the damn phone. I’m not here to chit-chat. I want information.’’

Says special assistant Bob Schaefer, 75: “Some people shy away from baseball guys. Rizz wants us around. He tells us, 'Everybody can looks at stats. I’m looking for guys who know how to win.' He believes in chemistry and culture.

“Some of these other guys are trying to find guys on Twitter. It’s embarrassing for baseball. You’d think in a $10 billion industry, you’d want experienced guys.’’

Said Jennings: “The thing about him is that he’s smart enough to change with the times, and incorporate the analytics as needed. But he’s also an evaluator at heart. He trusts his eyes. He trusts his people. And no one is more loyal.’’

And as long as he’s going old-school, Rizzo is making sure to keep the tradition of superstition alive, too.

He is the one who told his scouts to dress elegantly when they arrive at the World Series games, recommending they wear suits. Well, the scouts did just as instructed, but guess who showed up for Game 1 of the World Series in Houston looking like Bill Belichick, dressed in a red Nats hoodie?

“Hey, I’ve been wearing this during our winning streak,’’ Rizzo moaned. “Sorry, I can’t change now. I just can’t.’’
description: While analytics certainly play a role for the Nationals, GM Mike Rizzo has put scouting first, bringing several veteran scouts to his staff.
